bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wyndham B. Blanton, June 23, 1929

div1.p: Carter is interested in Blanton's planned medical history of Virginia and although her father's manuscript does not cover the time period Blanton is interested in, she answers as many questions as she can.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wyndham B. Blanton, June 23, 1929

opener.dateline:
Care Mrs. Bell Moon Maury,
“Dunlora,” Box 453,
Charlottesville, Virginia,
June 23, 1929.

div1.p: Your very interesting letter of June 21st. has just reached me.

A history of medicine in Virginia should certainly be a real contribution
to our literature. I shall await its appearance with the greatest interest.

1: The number, date, duration and severity of epidemics of yellow fever
in Virginia.

(See page 3, this letter re Beranger-Feraud's : Traité theorique
(et clinique...“ Pub. Paris. 1890)
2.: The authority for these epidemics. (See page 3, this letter as above)

I regret to say that I personally can give you no further data on either of the above, save that there
was certainly no yellow fever in Virginia until well after 1648, the date of the great
epidemis of 1648 in Yucatan and the French Antilles (reported by Lopez de Cogolludo and
Pèré du Tertre). These, Father counted as the beginning of “historic” yellow fever in
the Americas, as distinguished from the traditional.

As Dr. L. L. Williams, of our Service, may have told you, Father did not live to
complete his History of Yellow Fever, although each Section is a complete entity in it-
self--“like a flight of stairs,” as Father once said. This, because he was quite sure
he would not live to complete the entire book and would not undertake it until it was so
planned that his stopping short of the end would not interfere with the usefulness of
what had already been accomplished. It is true that the Section on Epidemiology (Section 1)
covers the ground up to June 30, 1925 (the night before the beginning of his final illness).
Section iii, however (the beginning of the purely historic part of the book) gives the
epidemiological history of the disease in detail only up to 1648 for the Americas
and to 1769 and 1778 (Lind and Schotte) for West Africa--i. e. to “historic yellow fever”
in both continents. Notwithstanding the 100 offodd years difference between these dates
for the two continents, Father considered that yellow fever originated in West Africa. The
epidemiological argument for this belief is deduced from many old historic books and MSS
MSS
-2-
in Mayan, Nahuatl, Spanish, French, Latin, Portuguese, and Italian, much of which had
never been translated into English until Father and I did sofor his book. I fear then
that the citation of this [unclear] literature would be of little use to you, as some of the literatureit is
quite inaccessible and feel that it would be much more satisfactory if you can wait until the
publication of Father's book, which we anticipate will take place in the near future. Dr.
Wade Hampton Frost, of the Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene, is doing the final editing,
having promised Father to do so before his death. It is a perfect arrangement, Father
thought the world of Frost, both as an epidemiologist and a friend and it means that the
the book will not suffer (save in not being completed) by Father's death.

Your No. 4: “Whether the Stegomyia fasciata was indigenous to Virginia or was
brought here on sailing vessels!”

Father considered that yellow fever was first brought from West Africa (this of
course including the islands adjacent thereto (as the Cape de Verdes and São Thomé): And
that, as I have previously stated, it first appeared in the Antilles and Yucatan. These
sailing vessels must also have brought the Stegomyia with them as, an epidemic of yellow fever con-
tracted by the crews at the port of departure (with no infectable or infected Stegomyia aboard) would have been over long before the end
of so long a sea-voyage. Whether it have been present on the ships there whether the causative organism 1st came aboard
in (a) man or (b) mosquito wld only matter in (b) adding the
period of extrinsic incubation to the time date of the infectivity of the steg, & the subsequent epidemic aboard ship. There are many other reasons for for believing there were no
Stegomyia in the Americas at the time of the the arrival of the Spaniards and English into
which I have not time to enter. Father's book takes up all these arguments in extenso.

No. 3: “How yellow fever reached the colony in the xvii Century when travel by sea
was as slow as it was.”

This question I have partly answered in the preceeding one. Yellow fever is
essentially a ship-borne disease and mosquitoes, either infected prior to leaving the
port of departure or breeding aboard and becoming infected from some of the crew in-
fected ashore, would stay on the ship indefinitely. Indeed, in the latter. They would
thus be capable of biting uninfected men at the port of arrival both aboard-ship and
--“disembarking,” begin breeding in places adjacent to the ship, spreading in time in
so far as climatic and sociological conditions permitted. By the latter, I mean that
the Stegomyia, in contradistinction to the Anopheles, is an urban not (domestic) form
odf mosquito.

Re your questions (1) and (2) I think the best book I can recommend is
Béranger-Féraud's: “Traité theorique et clinique de la fièvre jaune”...
Pub. Paris, 1890.

It has a Section (near the front of the book) entitled “Chronologie,” which
gives the dates (though not all accurately prior to 1648) of all epidemics of yellow
fever in both the Old and the New World. He also cites his original sources, so you
should thus be put in touch with an abundance of literature. N.B., however, that as
Béranger- Féraud believed in the American origin of yellow fever, you must keep this
fact in mind when reading of any epidemics in the New World prior thereto to 1648, in-
cluding the “coup de barre” of 1635 in Guadeloupe, which Hirsch, as I recollect, con-
siders the beginning of “historic yellow fever.” in the Americas. I do not recall what
Béranger-Féraud says about epidemics of yellow fever in Virginia, but I think you will
will find him satisfactory. Copy B. Féraud S. G's Library.

I am sorry not to be able to answer the above two questions of my own knowledge--
Father, of course, could have done so with the greatest ease, but, after he developed
angina, we were “working against time” to such an extent that there was no time for me to
get up on the detail of future parts of the work after working 18 hours a day on Section iii

Please give my very best remembrances to Dr. Williams when you see him. Also,
should either of you come to Charlottesville within the next month, I do hope that you
will come out to “Dunlora,” and give me some details of the History of Medicine in
Virginia. I know of nothing that would give me greater pleasure.
div1.closer:
Most truly yours, Laura Armistead Carter Dr. Wyndham B. Blanton,
828 West Franklin Street,
Richmond, Virginia.
